metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of desert station, 2023)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the desert station from January 1 to December 31, 2023. The site (100.9872°E, 42.1135°N) was located on a desert surface in the desert, which is near Ejin Banner, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 1054 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45AC; 5 and 10 m, north), wind speed profile (010C; 5 and 10 m, north), wind direction (020C, 10m), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0 m), soil moisture profile (ML3; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and Ta_10 m; RH_5 m and RH_10 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_5 m and Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, Ts_100 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, Ms_100 cm) (%).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2023-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) and Liu et al. (2023).

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is the role of an automatic weather station in data collection for meteorological research in arid regions?
Definition.Answer: An automatic weather station collects hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. These observations are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions, with data typically averaged over a 10-minute period.

Definition.Question: What constitutes the primary challenges of data collection in inland river basins within arid and semiarid areas?
Definition.Answer: The primary challenges include ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent occurrences of dust storms. These issues are especially prevalent in inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin.

Definition.Question: How is quality control typically enforced in the collection of meteorological data in arid environments?
Definition.Answer: Quality control involves ensuring data completeness by marking any missing data, removing duplicate records, and discarding data that exceed the physical meaning or instrument range. Suspicious data are highlighted, and date and time formats are standardized to maintain consistency and accuracy in the dataset.

Comparison.Question: How does the scope of datasets from oasis–desert systems differ from those in other arid regions regarding hydrometeorological parameters?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets from oasis–desert systems tend to include a broader range of hydrometeorological parameters, such as energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, alongside vegetation and soil parameters. In contrast, other arid region datasets might focus more narrowly on basic meteorological data and soil moisture profiles.

Interpretation.Answer: It can be inferred that understanding these long-term data patterns is crucial to maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems, which is significant for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, as well as supporting ecological security and sustainable development in oasis–desert areas.

Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges include ecological degradation, which affects the stability of observation systems, and the need for consistent long-term data to understand oasis–desert interactions, crucial for protecting ecological stability and supporting sustainable development.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing automated weather stations with 10-minute average periods for data collection in arid and semi-arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing automated weather stations with 10-minute average periods can provide a detailed temporal resolution of hydrometeorological data, enabling a comprehensive understanding of short-term variations in energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid and semi-arid regions. This can enhance our ability to monitor and model the ecological dynamics of oasis–desert systems, contributing to sustainable development and ecological security.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating data from multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations allows for a spatially comprehensive analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which is crucial for understanding oasis–desert interactions. This can lead to insights into ecological stability, resource management, and the socioeconomic development of oases, as well as contributing to the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Goal Orientation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.

Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis by understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these areas.

Goal Orientation.Answer: It is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring the quality control of meteorological data collected from automatic weather stations in arid and semiarid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The quality control of meteorological data involves ensuring that there are 144 data points collected daily, marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that exceeds physical or instrumental constraints, flagging data with uncertainty in red, and standardizing the format of date and time.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation and technology are necessary to enable the continuous collection of hydrometeorological data in arid desert regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of automatic weather stations with sensors for air temperature, humidity, air pressure, precipitation, wind speed and direction, radiation, and soil parameters, as well as eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux data, are necessary to enable continuous data collection in such environments.

Enablement.Question: How do quality control measures enable the integrity and reliability of meteorological datasets collected in remote desert locations?
Enablement.Answer: Quality control measures such as ensuring a consistent number of data points per day, marking missing or questionable data, and removing data that exceed physical or instrument limits, help maintain the integrity and reliability of the datasets collected in remote locations.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in maintaining data quality and consistency in long-term observational datasets in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological environmental degradation, such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms, which can impact data consistency and quality.

Expectation.Question: What could be the anticipated difficulties in achieving accurate measurements of carbon and methane fluxes in oasis–desert areas?
Expectation.Answer: Oasis–desert systems are complex and require understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics. These areas have been found to be carbon sinks, affecting the carbon balance and playing a role in the global carbon cycle, making accurate measurement challenging.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of the data quality control measures applied in meteorological data collection in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of data quality control measures in meteorological data collection within arid regions can be considered robust, as they include ensuring daily data completeness, removing duplicates, handling outliers, and flagging questionable data. These steps help maintain data integrity and reliability, which are crucial for long-term observations and ecological studies in such challenging environments.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges faced in collecting accurate hydrometeorological data in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Judgmental.Answer: Collecting accurate hydrometeorological data in arid and semiarid inland river basins is challenging due to ecological degradation, such as drying rivers, vegetation loss, desertification, and dust storms. These conditions complicate data collection and require robust methodologies and quality control measures to ensure data accuracy and reliability.

Assertion.Answer: Datasets from oasis-desert systems contribute to understanding the ecological balance by providing quantitative insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. These datasets help in recognizing interactions within the oasis-desert systems, supporting ecological stability, and guiding socioeconomic development by maintaining the balance necessary for sustainable oasis development.

Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods in arid and semi-arid regions such as the 黑河流域地表过程综合观测网 include using automatic weather stations to monitor meteorological elements like air temperature, relative humidity, air pressure, precipitation, wind speed and direction, and radiation. Instruments are positioned at various heights and orientations to ensure comprehensive data acquisition. Challenges include ensuring data quality and dealing with ecological degradation crises such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and desertification.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the procedures for data processing and quality control applied to meteorological datasets, emphasizing methods to handle missing or erroneous data.
